title: Farm Tractor Safety : More than Plows and PTOs - Part 6

tasks.task: Ensuring Safety Procedures when Operating a Tractor
subtasks: Assume the tractor operator may not see you; maintain a safe distance.
In the area between a running tractor and implement, ensure the tractor is stopped, PTO off, moving parts stopped, and driver acknowledges before entering.
Familiarize yourself with the field before starting work; identify hazards.
Operate the front end loader at low load heights; add ballast if necessary to maintain stability.
Drive at reduced speed when towing a heavy load; avoid excessive speed.
Slow down for blind corners, curves, and crossings; anticipate traffic to prevent collisions.
Reduce speed on slopes; avoid transaxle depressions or gear changes.
Operate with caution during adverse weather; extinguish engine during thunderstorms.
Exercise vigilance when driving on public roads; ensure lights and warning signs are functional.
Navigate turns safely, using mirrors and turn signals; wait for safe conditions.
Proper shutdown procedures: check parking brakes, lower implements, park in neutral, shut off engine, and remove key.

tasks.task: Maintaining Tractor Stability and Load Security
subtasks: Secure loads appropriately with front end loader, using correct attachments (e.g., spear for round bales, grapple forks for size-fitting bales).
Distribute ballast appropriately to counteract loading and maintain center of gravity.
Inspect equipment for stability before moving, especially with heavy or unbalanced loads.
Secure trailers and implements correctly for towing.
Avoid overloading the tractor and ensure proper distribution of weight for stability.
Adjust driving speed and caution level when visibility is reduced or during inclement weather.
Utilize alternative routes or seek shelter if severe weather approaches during operations.
Take immediate action to seek safe refuge, such as getting off the tractor and assuming a lightning-safe position.

tasks.task: Safe Operating Practices on Public Roads
subtasks: Equip the tractor with functional hazard lights, headlights, tail lights, turn signals, and a Slow Moving Vehicle (SMV) emblem for visibility.
Combine brake pedals for safety and prevent roll-overs in case of foot slippage.
Avoid driving on public roads at night due to poor visibility and traffic challenges.
Approach left turns with caution, using mirrors, signaling, and ensuring clear passage.
Park safely by choosing level ground, using wheel chocks if necessary, and cooling the engine before refueling.
